review.title: Sensitivity analysis, multilinearity and beyond
review.abstract: Sensitivity methods for the analysis of the outputs of discrete Bayesian networks have been extensively studied and implemented in different software packages. These methods usually focus on the study of sensitivity functions and on the impact of a parameter change to the Chan-Darwiche distance. Although not fully recognized, the majority of these results heavily rely on the multilinear structure of atomic probabilities in terms of the conditional probability parameters associated with this type of network. By defining a statistical model through the polynomial expression of its associated defining conditional probabilities, we develop a unifying approach to sensitivity methods applicable to a large suite of models including extensions of Bayesian networks, for instance context-specific and dynamic ones, and chain event graphs. By then focusing on models whose defining polynomial is multilinear, our algebraic approach enables us to prove that the Chan-Darwiche distance is minimized for a certain class of multi-parameter contemporaneous variations when parameters are proportionally covaried.

metadata.title: Sensitivity analysis: multilinearity and beyond

sections.text: Sensitivity methods for analyzing the results of discrete Bayesian networks have been extensively studied and implemented in various software packages. These methods typically focus on the study of sensitivity functions and the effects of a parameter change on the Chan-Darwiche distance. Although most of these results are not fully recognized, they are strongly based on the multilinear structure of atomic probabilities with respect to the conditional probability parameters associated with this type of network. By defining a statistical model by the polynomial expression of the conditional probabilities associated with it, we develop a unifying approach to sensitivity methods that is applicable to a wide range of models, including extensions of Bayean networks, such as context-specific and dynamic, and chain event graphs. By then focusing on models whose definition is polyminimially multilinear, our algebraic approach allows us to prove that the Chan-Darwiche parameters are a specific class for specific time parameters.

sections.heading: 5. Sensitivity analysis in non-multilinear models
sections.text: For multilinear models, we have created a unifying framework to perform different sensitivity analyses by deriving closed forms for both sensitivity functions and CD distance. Unfortunately, this is not possible for non-multilinear parametric models, as they depend on the degree of both indefinite and covaried parameters, which are not necessarily the same. However, the representation of the model by its interpolating polynomial factors enables us to study the central properties of both sensitivity functions and CD distance. As in Section 3, we are distinguished from the covaried parameters in which we represent the model by its interpolar polynomial factors.

sections.heading: 6. Multi-way sensitivity analysis in multilinear models
sections.text: So far, we have focused on a one-way sensitivity analysis, which is most commonly performed in practice. We are now looking at reusable sensitivity methods, in which more than one parameter is varied simultaneously. We will first focus on a specific type of analysis, which is usually referred to as completely single CPT analyses. In this type of method, one parameter is given from each individual probability table, which contains a complete probability table. We are now generalizing the complete CPT method from BNs to general multilinear models. This type of analysis is easier than other reusable methods because the parameters are varied.

sections.heading: 7. Discussion
sections.text: Defining a parametric model by its interpolating polynomial has proven useful in investigating how changes in the input probabilities affect an output of interest. We have shown that standard results for BN models apply to a large number of other models, such as context-specific BNs and square CEGs. Within this framework, the flexibility of interpolating polynomial representation allowed us to investigate an even larger class of models, such as DBNs and non-square CEGs, extending sensitivity methods to dynamic settings. Within this framework, both sensitivity functions and CD distances exhibit different characteristics than in the simpler multilinear case, with the potential for even more informative sensitivity investigations. We then demonstrated the optimality of the proportional covariation scheme in full conditional CPT analysis not only for BNs, but also for multilinear models that we have focused on the discrete function of probability models in terms of determining determinable probability.
